title: Solving Problems on Generalized Convex Graphs via Mim-WidthBrettell and Paulusma received support from the Leverhulme Trust (RPG-2016-258). Bonomo received support from CONICET (PIP 11220200100084CO) and UBACyT (20020170100495BA and 20020160100095BA). Brettell was also supported by a Rutherford Foundation Postdoctoral Fellowship, administered by the Royal Society Te ApÄrangi. An extended abstract of the paper appeared in the proceedings of WADS 2021 [7].

sections.introduction:
Many computationally hard graph problems can be solved efficiently if we place constraints on the input.
Instead of solving individual problems in an ad hoc way we may try to decompose the vertex set of the input graph into large sets of â€œsimilarly behavingâ€ vertices and to exploit this decomposition for an algorithmic speed up that works for many problems simultaneously. This requires some notion of an â€œoptimalâ€ vertex decomposition, which depends on the type of vertex decomposition used and which may relate to the minimum number of sets or the maximum size of a set in a vertex decomposition. An optimal vertex decomposition gives us the â€œwidthâ€ of the graph. A graph class has bounded width if every graph in the class has width at most some constant cğ‘c. Boundedness of width is often the underlying reason why a graph-class-specific algorithm runs efficiently: in this case, the proof that the algorithm is efficient for some special graph class reduces to a proof showing that the width of the class is bounded by some constant. We will give examples, but also refer to the
surveysÂ 4    
for further details and examples. Width parameters differ in strength. A width parameter pğ‘p dominates a width parameterÂ qğ‘q if there is a functionÂ fğ‘“f such that pâ€‹(G)ğ‘ğºp(G) is at most fâ€‹(qâ€‹(G))ğ‘“ğ‘ğºf(q(G)) for every graphÂ GğºG. If pğ‘p dominates qğ‘q but qğ‘q does not dominate pğ‘p, then we say that pğ‘p is more powerful than qğ‘q. If both pğ‘p and qğ‘q dominate each other, then pğ‘p and qğ‘q are equivalent.
If neither pğ‘p is more powerful than qğ‘q nor qğ‘q is more powerful than pğ‘p, then pğ‘p and qğ‘q are incomparable.
If pğ‘p is more powerful than qğ‘q, then
the class of graphs for which pğ‘p is bounded is larger than the class of graphs for which qğ‘q is bounded and so efficient algorithms for bounded pğ‘p have greater applicability with respect to the graphs under consideration.
The trade-off is that fewer problems exhibit an efficient algorithm for the parameter pğ‘p, compared to the parameter qğ‘q. This notion of powerfulness leads to a large hierarchy of width parameters, in which new width parameters continue to be defined,
for example, graph functionalityÂ  in 2019 and twin-widthÂ  in 2020.
The well-known parameters boolean-width, clique-width, module-width and rank-width are equivalent to each otherÂ 6 0 4. They are more powerful than the equivalent parameters branch-width and treewidthÂ  5  but less powerful than mim-widthÂ , which is less powerful than sim-widthÂ . To give another example, thinness is more powerful than path-widthÂ , but less powerful than mim-width and incomparable to clique-width or treewidthÂ . For each group of equivalent width parameters, a growing set of NP-complete problems is known to be tractable on graph classes of bounded width. Proving the latter for some graph class often immediately tells us that many problems are tractable for that class without the need for constructing algorithms for each problem.
However, there are still large families of graph classes, and many width parameters, for which it is not known whether the class has bounded width. Our Focus.
We consider the relatively new width parameter mim-width, which we define below.
Recently, we showed inÂ 3 4 that boundedness of mim-width is the underlying reason why
some specific hereditary graph classes, characterized by two forbidden induced subgraphs,
admit polynomial-time algorithms for a range of problems including kğ‘˜k-Colouring and its generalization List kğ‘˜k-Colouring (the algorithms are
given inÂ   ).
Here we prove that the same holds for certain superclasses of convex graphs known in the literature.
Essentially all the known polynomial-time algorithms for such classes are obtained by reducing to the class of convex graphs. We show that our new approach
via mim-width simplifies the analysis, unifies the sporadic approaches
and explains the reductions to convex graphs. Mim-width.
A set of edges Mğ‘€M in a graph GğºG is a matching if no two edges of Mğ‘€M share an endpoint. A matching Mğ‘€M is induced if there is no edge in GğºG between vertices of different edges of Mğ‘€M. Let (A,AÂ¯)ğ´Â¯ğ´(A,\overline{A}) be a partition of the vertex set of a graph GğºG. Then Gâ€‹[A,AÂ¯]ğºğ´Â¯ğ´G[A,\overline{A}] denotes the bipartite subgraph of GğºG induced by the edges with one endpoint in Ağ´A and the other in AÂ¯Â¯ğ´\overline{A}.
VatshelleÂ  introduced the notion of maximum induced matching width, also called mim-width. Mim-width measures
the extent to which it is possible to decompose a graph GğºG along certain vertex partitions (A,AÂ¯)ğ´Â¯ğ´(A,\overline{A}) such that the size of a maximum induced matching in Gâ€‹[A,AÂ¯]ğºğ´Â¯ğ´G[A,\overline{A}] is small. The kind of vertex partitions permitted stems from classical branch decompositions,
as we explain below. A branch decomposition for a graphÂ GğºG is a pair (T,Î´)ğ‘‡ğ›¿(T,\delta), where Tğ‘‡T is a subcubic tree and Î´ğ›¿\delta is a bijection fromÂ Vâ€‹(G)ğ‘‰ğºV(G) to the leaves of Tğ‘‡T.
Every edge eâˆˆEâ€‹(T)ğ‘’ğ¸ğ‘‡e\in E(T) partitions the leaves of Tğ‘‡T into two classes, Lesubscriptğ¿ğ‘’L_{e} and LeÂ¯Â¯subscriptğ¿ğ‘’\overline{L_{e}}, depending on which component of Tâˆ’eğ‘‡ğ‘’T-e they belong to.
Hence, eğ‘’e induces a partition (Ae,AeÂ¯)subscriptğ´ğ‘’Â¯subscriptğ´ğ‘’(A_{e},\overline{A_{e}}) of Vâ€‹(G)ğ‘‰ğºV(G), where Î´â€‹(Ae)=Leğ›¿subscriptğ´ğ‘’subscriptğ¿ğ‘’\delta(A_{e})=L_{e} and Î´â€‹(AeÂ¯)=LeÂ¯ğ›¿Â¯subscriptğ´ğ‘’Â¯subscriptğ¿ğ‘’\delta(\overline{A_{e}})=\overline{L_{e}}.
Let cutmimGâ€‹(Ae,AeÂ¯)subscriptcutmimğºsubscriptğ´ğ‘’Â¯subscriptğ´ğ‘’\mathrm{cutmim}_{G}(A_{e},\overline{A_{e}}) be the size of a maximum induced matching in Gâ€‹[Ae,AeÂ¯]ğºsubscriptğ´ğ‘’Â¯subscriptğ´ğ‘’G[A_{e},\overline{A_{e}}].
Then the mim-width mimwGâ€‹(T,Î´)subscriptmimwğºğ‘‡ğ›¿\mathrm{mimw}_{G}(T,\delta) of (T,Î´)ğ‘‡ğ›¿(T,\delta) is the maximum value of cutmimGâ€‹(Ae,AeÂ¯)subscriptcutmimğºsubscriptğ´ğ‘’Â¯subscriptğ´ğ‘’\mathrm{cutmim}_{G}(A_{e},\overline{A_{e}}) over all edges eâˆˆEâ€‹(T)ğ‘’ğ¸ğ‘‡e\in E(T). The mim-width mimwâ€‹(G)mimwğº\mathrm{mimw}(G) of GğºG is the minimum value of mimwGâ€‹(T,Î´)subscriptmimwğºğ‘‡ğ›¿\mathrm{mimw}_{G}(T,\delta) over all branch decompositions (T,Î´)ğ‘‡ğ›¿(T,\delta) for GğºG.
See FigureÂ 1 for an example of a branch decomposition for a graph. A caterpillar is a tree Tğ‘‡T that contains a pathÂ Pğ‘ƒP, the backbone of Tğ‘‡T, such that every vertex not on Pğ‘ƒP has a neighbour onÂ Pğ‘ƒP (the tree in FigureÂ 1Â (b) is an example of a caterpillar).
A linear branch decomposition for a graphÂ GğºG is a pair (T,Î´)ğ‘‡ğ›¿(T,\delta), where Tğ‘‡T is a caterpillar and Î´ğ›¿\delta is a bijection fromÂ Vâ€‹(G)ğ‘‰ğºV(G) to the leaves
ofÂ Tğ‘‡T. The linear mim-width of GğºG is the minimum value of mimwGâ€‹(T,Î´)subscriptmimwğºğ‘‡ğ›¿\mathrm{mimw}_{G}(T,\delta) over all linear branch decompositions (T,Î´)ğ‘‡ğ›¿(T,\delta) for GğºG. Note that FigureÂ 1 is in fact an example of a linear branch decomposition. The problems of computing the mim-width and linear mim-width of a graph are NP-hardÂ 6. Moreover, approximating the mim-width in polynomial time within a constant factor of the optimal is not possible unless ğ–­ğ–¯=ğ–¹ğ–¯ğ–¯ğ–­ğ–¯ğ–¹ğ–¯ğ–¯\mathsf{NP}=\mathsf{ZPP}Â 6.
It is not known how to compute in polynomial time a branch decomposition for a graphÂ GğºG whose mim-width is bounded by some function in
mimwâ€‹(G)mimwğº\mathrm{mimw}(G).
Nevertheless, if GğºG is from some graph classÂ ğ’¢ğ’¢{\cal G} of bounded mim-width, then this is often possible. In that case,
the mim-width of ğ’¢ğ’¢{\cal G} is said to be quickly computable. One can then try to develop a polynomial-time algorithm for the graph problem under consideration via dynamic programming over the computed branch decomposition. We
give examples of such problems later. Convex Graphs and Generalizations.
A bipartite graph G=(A,B,E)ğºğ´ğµğ¸G=(A,B,E) is convex if there exists a path Pğ‘ƒP with Vâ€‹(P)=Ağ‘‰ğ‘ƒğ´V(P)=A such that the neighbours in Ağ´A of each bâˆˆBğ‘ğµb\in B induce a connected subpath of Pğ‘ƒP. Convex graphs generalize bipartite permutation graphs
(see, e.g., 0)
and form a well-studied graph class.
They were introduced in the sixties, by Glover , to solve a special type of matching problem arising in some industrial application. Another early paper solving matching problems on convex graphs is by Lipski and Preparata . Belmonte and Vatshelle  proved that the mim-width of convex graphs is bounded and quickly computable.
We consider superclasses of convex graphs and research to what extent mim-width can play a role in obtaining polynomial-time algorithms for problems on these classes. Let â„‹â„‹{\cal H} be a family of graphs.
A bipartite graph G=(A,B,E)ğºğ´ğµğ¸G=(A,B,E) is â„‹â„‹{\cal H}-convex if there exists a graph Hâˆˆâ„‹ğ»â„‹H\in{\cal H} with Vâ€‹(H)=Ağ‘‰ğ»ğ´V(H)=A such that the set of neighbours in Ağ´A of each bâˆˆBğ‘ğµb\in B induces a connected subgraph ofÂ Hğ»H.
If â„‹â„‹{\cal H} consists of all paths, we obtain the class of convex graphs.
Recall that a caterpillar is a tree Tğ‘‡T that contains a
pathÂ Pğ‘ƒP (the backbone), such that every vertex not on Pğ‘ƒP has a neighbour onÂ Pğ‘ƒP. A caterpillar with a backbone consisting of one vertex is a star.
A comb is a caterpillar such that every backbone vertex has exactly one neighbour outside the backbone.
The subdivision of an edge uâ€‹vğ‘¢ğ‘£uv replaces uâ€‹vğ‘¢ğ‘£uv by a new vertex wğ‘¤w and edges uâ€‹wğ‘¢ğ‘¤uw and wâ€‹uğ‘¤ğ‘¢wu. A triad is a tree that can be obtained from a 444-vertex star after a sequence of subdivisions.
For t,Î”â‰¥0ğ‘¡Î”0t,\Delta\geq 0, a (t,Î”)ğ‘¡Î”(t,\Delta)-tree is a tree with maximum degree at most Î”Î”\Delta and containing at most tğ‘¡t vertices of degree at leastÂ 333; note that, for example, a triad is a (1,3)13(1,3)-tree.
If â„‹â„‹{\cal H} consists of all cycles, all trees, all stars, all triads, all combs or all (t,Î”)ğ‘¡Î”(t,\Delta)-trees, then we obtain the class of circular convex graphs, tree convex graphs, star convex graphs, triad convex graphs, comb convex graphs or (t,Î”)ğ‘¡Î”(t,\Delta)-tree convex graphs, respectively. See FigureÂ 1 for an example of a circular convex graph (this class was introduced by Liang and Blum  to model certain scheduling problems). To show the relationships between the above graph classes we need some extra terminology.
Let ğ’t,Î”subscriptğ’ğ‘¡Î”\mathcal{C}_{t,\Delta}Â be the class of (t,Î”)ğ‘¡Î”(t,\Delta)-tree convex graphs. For fixed tğ‘¡t or Î”Î”\Delta, we have increasing sequences ğ’t,0âŠ†ğ’t,1âŠ†â‹¯subscriptğ’ğ‘¡0subscriptğ’ğ‘¡1â‹¯\mathcal{C}_{t,0}\subseteq\mathcal{C}_{t,1}\subseteq\cdots and ğ’0,Î”âŠ†ğ’1,Î”âŠ†â‹¯subscriptğ’0Î”subscriptğ’1Î”â‹¯\mathcal{C}_{0,\Delta}\subseteq\mathcal{C}_{1,\Delta}\subseteq\cdots. For tâˆˆâ„•ğ‘¡â„•t\in\mathbb{N}, the class of (t,âˆ)ğ‘¡(t,\infty)-tree convex graphs is â‹ƒÎ”âˆˆâ„•ğ’t,Î”subscriptÎ”â„•subscriptğ’ğ‘¡Î”\bigcup_{\Delta\in\mathbb{N}}\mathcal{C}_{t,\Delta}, denoted by ğ’t,âˆsubscriptğ’ğ‘¡\mathcal{C}_{t,\infty}. Similarly, for Î”âˆˆâ„•Î”â„•\Delta\in\mathbb{N}, the class of (âˆ,Î”)Î”(\infty,\Delta)-tree convex graphs is â‹ƒtâˆˆâ„•ğ’t,Î”subscriptğ‘¡â„•subscriptğ’ğ‘¡Î”\bigcup_{t\in\mathbb{N}}\mathcal{C}_{t,\Delta}, denoted by ğ’âˆ,Î”subscriptğ’Î”\mathcal{C}_{\infty,\Delta}.
Hence,
ğ’t,âˆsubscriptğ’ğ‘¡\mathcal{C}_{t,\infty} and ğ’âˆ,Î”subscriptğ’Î”\mathcal{C}_{\infty,\Delta} are the set-theoretic limits of the increasing sequences {ğ’t,Î”}Î”âˆˆâ„•subscriptsubscriptğ’ğ‘¡Î”Î”â„•\{\mathcal{C}_{t,\Delta}\}_{\Delta\in\mathbb{N}} and {ğ’t,Î”}tâˆˆâ„•subscriptsubscriptğ’ğ‘¡Î”ğ‘¡â„•\{\mathcal{C}_{t,\Delta}\}_{t\in\mathbb{N}}, respectively. The class of (âˆ,âˆ)(\infty,\infty)-tree convex graphs is â‹ƒt,Î”âˆˆâ„•ğ’t,Î”subscriptğ‘¡Î”â„•subscriptğ’ğ‘¡Î”\bigcup_{t,\Delta\in\mathbb{N}}\mathcal{C}_{t,\Delta}, which coincides with the class of tree convex graphs. Notice that the class of convex graphs coincides with ğ’t,2subscriptğ’ğ‘¡2\mathcal{C}_{t,2}, for any tâˆˆâ„•âˆª{âˆ}ğ‘¡â„•t\in\mathbb{N}\cup\{\infty\}, and with ğ’0,Î”subscriptğ’0Î”\mathcal{C}_{0,\Delta}, for any Î”âˆˆâ„•âˆª{âˆ}Î”â„•\Delta\in\mathbb{N}\cup\{\infty\}. The class of star convex graphs coincides with ğ’1,âˆsubscriptğ’1\mathcal{C}_{1,\infty}. Moreover, each triad convex graph belongs toÂ ğ’1,3subscriptğ’13\mathcal{C}_{1,3} and each comb convex graph belongs to ğ’âˆ,3subscriptğ’3\mathcal{C}_{\infty,3}. A bipartite graph is chordal bipartite if every induced cycle in it has exactly four vertices.
Every convex graph is chordal bipartite (see, e.g., 0) and every chordal bipartite graph is tree convex (seeÂ  ).
In FigureÂ 2 we display the relationships between these classes. Brault-Baron et al.Â 2 proved that chordal bipartite graphs have unbounded mim-width. Hence, the result ofÂ  for convex graphs cannot be generalized to chordal bipartite graphs. We determine the mim-width of the other classes in FigureÂ 2 but first discuss known algorithmic results for these classes. Known Results.
Belmonte and Vatshelle  and Bui-Xuan et al.Â 7 proved that so-called Locally Checkable Vertex Subset and Vertex Partitioning (LC-VSVP) problems, first defined inÂ 8,
are polynomial-time solvable on graph classes whose mim-width is bounded and quickly computable.
This result was extended by Bergougnoux and KantÃ©Â [ref]3 to variants of such problems with additional constraints on connectivity or acyclicity.
Each of the problems mentioned below is a special case of a Locally Checkable Vertex Subset (LCVS) problem
possibly with one of the two extra constraints.
We refer to the listed papers for the definitions of the problems, as we do not need them here. Panda et al.Â 2 proved that Induced Matching is polynomial-time solvable for
circular convex and triad convex graphs, but NP-complete for star convex and comb convex graphs. Pandey and Panda 3 proved that Dominating Set is polynomial-time solvable for circular convex, triad convex and
(1,Î”)1Î”(1,\Delta)-tree convex graphs for every Î”â‰¥1Î”1\Delta\geq 1. Liu et al.Â  proved that Connected Dominating Set is polynomial-time solvable for circular convex and triad convex graphs. Chen et al.Â 8 showed that Dominating Set, Connected Dominating Set
and Total Dominating Set are
NP-complete for star convex and comb convex graphs. Lu et al.Â  proved that Independent Dominating Set is polynomial-time solvable for circular convex and triad convex graphs. The latter result was previously shown inÂ 7 using a dynamic programming approach instead of a reduction to convex graphsÂ . Song et al.Â 7 showed in fact a stronger result, namely that Independent Dominating Set
is polynomial-time solvable for (t,Î”)ğ‘¡Î”(t,\Delta)-tree convex graphs for every tâ‰¥1ğ‘¡1t\geq 1 and Î”â‰¥3Î”3\Delta\geq 3. They also showed that Independent Dominating Set is NP-complete for star convex and comb convex graphsÂ 7. Hence, they obtained a dichotomy: Independent Dominating Set is polynomial-time solvable for (t,Î”)ğ‘¡Î”(t,\Delta)-tree convex graphs for every tâ‰¥1ğ‘¡1t\geq 1 and Î”â‰¥3Î”3\Delta\geq 3 but NP-complete for (âˆ,3)3(\infty,3)-tree convex graphs and (1,âˆ)1(1,\infty)-tree convex graphs. The same dichotomy (explicitly formulated inÂ 1)
holds for Feedback Vertex Set and is obtained similarly. Namely, Jiang et al.Â  proved that this problem is polynomial-time solvable for triad convex graphs and mentioned that their algorithm can be generalized to (t,Î”)ğ‘¡Î”(t,\Delta)-tree convex graphs for every tâ‰¥1ğ‘¡1t\geq 1 and Î”â‰¥3Î”3\Delta\geq 3.
Jiang et al.Â  proved that Feedback Vertex Set is NP-complete for star convex and comb convex graphs.
In addition, Liu et al.Â  proved that Feedback Vertex Set is polynomial-time solvable for circular convex graphs, whereas Jiang et al.Â  proved that the Weighted Feedback Vertex Set problem is polynomial-time solvable for triad convex graphs. It turns out that the above problems are polynomial-time solvable on circular convex graphs and subclasses of (t,Î”)ğ‘¡Î”(t,\Delta)-tree convex graphs, but NP-complete for star convex graphs and comb convex graphs.
In contrast, Panda and ChaudharyÂ 1 proved that Dominating Induced Matching is not only polynomial-time solvable on circular convex and triad convex graphs, but also on star convex graphs.
Nevertheless, we notice a common pattern: many dominating set, induced matching and graph transversal type of problems are polynomial-time solvable for (t,Î”)ğ‘¡Î”(t,\Delta)-tree convex graphs, for every tâ‰¥1ğ‘¡1t\geq 1 and Î”â‰¥3Î”3\Delta\geq 3, and NP-complete for comb convex graphs, and thus for (âˆ,3)3(\infty,3)-tree convex graphs, and star convex graphs, or equivalently, (1,âˆ)1(1,\infty)-tree convex graphs. Moreover, essentially all the polynomial-time algorithms reduce the input to a convex graph. Our Results.
We simplify the analysis, unify the above approaches and explain the reductions to convex graphs, using mim-width. We prove three results that, together with the fact that chordal bipartite graphs have unbounded mim-widthÂ 2, explain the dotted line in FigureÂ 2. The first two results generalize the result of  for convex graphs. The third result gives two new reasons why tree convex graphs (that is, (âˆ,âˆ)(\infty,\infty)-tree convex graphs) have unbounded mim-width. The mim-width of the class of circular convex graphs is bounded and quickly computable. For every t,Î”âˆˆâ„•ğ‘¡Î”â„•t,\Delta\in\mathbb{N} with tâ‰¥1ğ‘¡1t\geq 1 and Î”â‰¥3Î”3\Delta\geq 3,
the mim-width of the class of (t,Î”)ğ‘¡Î”(t,\Delta)-tree convex graphs is bounded and quickly computable. The class of star convex graphs and the class of comb convex graphs have unbounded mim-width. Hence, we obtain a structural dichotomy (recall that star convex graphs are the (1,âˆ)1(1,\infty)-tree convex graphs and that
comb convex graphs are (âˆ,3)3(\infty,3)-tree convex): Let t,Î”âˆˆâ„•âˆª{âˆ}ğ‘¡Î”â„•t,\Delta\in\mathbb{N}\cup\{\infty\} with tâ‰¥1ğ‘¡1t\geq 1 and Î”â‰¥3Î”3\Delta\geq 3.
The class of (t,Î”)ğ‘¡Î”(t,\Delta)-tree convex graphs has bounded mim-width if and only if {t,Î”}âˆ©{âˆ}=âˆ…ğ‘¡Î”\{t,\Delta\}\cap\{\infty\}=\varnothing. Algorithmic Consequences.
As discussed, the following six problems were shown to be ğ–­ğ–¯ğ–­ğ–¯\mathsf{NP}-complete for star convex and comb convex graphs, and thus for (1,âˆ)1(1,\infty)-tree convex graphs and (âˆ,3)3(\infty,3)-tree convex graphs:
Feedback Vertex Set [ref]3 ;
Dominating Set, Connected Dominating Set, Total Dominating Set 8;
Independent Dominating Set 7;
Induced MatchingÂ 2.
These problems are examples of LCVS problems,
possibly with connectivity or acyclicity constraints. Hence, they are polynomial-time solvable for every graph class whose mim-width is bounded and quickly
computableÂ  [ref]3 7.
Recall that the same holds for Weighted Feedback Vertex SetÂ  and (Weighted) Subset Feedback Vertex SetÂ ; these three problems generalize Feedback Vertex Set and are thus NP-complete for
star convex graphs and comb convex graphs.
Combining these results with CorollaryÂ 1 yields the following complexity dichotomy. Let t,Î”âˆˆâ„•âˆª{âˆ}ğ‘¡Î”â„•t,\Delta\in\mathbb{N}\cup\{\infty\} with
tâ‰¥1ğ‘¡1t\geq 1, Î”â‰¥3Î”3\Delta\geq 3 and Î Î \Pi be one of the nine problems mentioned above,
restricted to (t,Î”)ğ‘¡Î”(t,\Delta)-tree convex graphs.
If {t,Î”}âˆ©{âˆ}=âˆ…ğ‘¡Î”\{t,\Delta\}\cap\{\infty\}=\varnothing, then Î Î \Pi is polynomial-time solvable; otherwise, Î Î \Pi is NP-complete. It is worth noting that this complexity dichotomy does not hold for all LCVS problems; recall that Dominating Induced Matching is polynomial-time solvable on star convex graphsÂ 1. TheoremsÂ 1.1 andÂ 1.2, combined with the result ofÂ 7, imply that this problem is also polynomial-time solvable on circular convex graphs and (t,Î”)ğ‘¡Î”(t,\Delta)-tree convex graphs for every tâ‰¥1ğ‘¡1t\geq 1 and Î”â‰¥3Î”3\Delta\geq 3. Our results have further algorithmic consequences.
For every fixed integerÂ kâ‰¥1ğ‘˜1k\geq 1, the kğ‘˜k-Colouring problem is an example of an LC-VSVP problem. KwonÂ 2 observed that
even its generalization List kğ‘˜k-Colouring is polynomial-time solvable on graph classes whose mim-width is bounded and quickly computable (seeÂ 4 for details). Hence, TheoremsÂ 1.1 andÂ 1.2, combined with Kwonâ€™s observationÂ 2,
also generalize a result of DÃ­az et al.Â 5 for List kğ‘˜k-Colouring on convex graphs to
circular convex and (t,Î”)ğ‘¡Î”(t,\Delta)-tree convex graphs (for any fixed tâ‰¥1ğ‘¡1t\geq 1, Î”â‰¥3Î”3\Delta\geq 3).
We prove the following result (note that the complexity of List 333-Colouring for comb convex graphs is still unresolved). For kâ‰¥4ğ‘˜4k\geq 4, List kğ‘˜k-Colouring is NP-complete for star convex graphs and comb convex graphs,
while List 333-Colouring is polynomial-time solvable for star convex graphs. Thus, in addition to CorollaryÂ 2, we obtain the following corollary for yet another problem. For kâ‰¥4ğ‘˜4k\geq 4 and t,Î”âˆˆâ„•âˆª{âˆ}ğ‘¡Î”â„•t,\Delta\in\mathbb{N}\cup\{\infty\} with
tâ‰¥1ğ‘¡1t\geq 1, Î”â‰¥3Î”3\Delta\geq 3, List kğ‘˜k-Colouring,
restricted to (t,Î”)ğ‘¡Î”(t,\Delta)-tree convex graphs, is polynomial-time solvable
if {t,Î”}âˆ©{âˆ}=âˆ…ğ‘¡Î”\{t,\Delta\}\cap\{\infty\}=\varnothing, and NP-complete otherwise. Outline.
We prove TheoremsÂ 1.1â€“1.3 in SectionsÂ 2â€“4, respectively, by showing additional structural results.
First, in SectionÂ 2, we prove TheoremÂ 1.1 by showing a similar but stronger result for linear mim-width of circular convex graphs.
Next, in SectionÂ 3, we prove a stronger version of TheoremÂ 1.2; namely we prove the result for thinness, a relatively recent graph width parameter introduced inÂ .
This replaces the more direct proof given inÂ .
Finally, in SectionÂ 4, we prove that TheoremÂ 1.3 follows from a stronger result as well: we prove that star convex graphs and comb convex graphs have unbounded sim-width. Recall that the latter width parameter is more powerful than mim-widthÂ . The above additional results naturally beg the question for a more refined analysis on width parameters for generalized convex classes.
We perform this analysis in SectionÂ 5. There, we consider a hierarchy of width parameters, which include mim-width and thinness. We determine exactly which of the generalized convex classes considered in the previous sections have bounded width for each of these parameters.
We are not yet aware of any new algorithmic results arising from this analysis,
but in SectionÂ 7 we give some directions for future research, after proving TheoremÂ 1.4 in SectionÂ 6. Preliminaries.
We consider only finite graphs G=(V,E)ğºğ‘‰ğ¸G=(V,E) with no loops and no multiple edges.
For vâˆˆVğ‘£ğ‘‰v\in V, the neighbourhood NGâ€‹(v)subscriptğ‘ğºğ‘£N_{G}(v) is the set of vertices adjacent to vğ‘£v. The degree dâ€‹(v)ğ‘‘ğ‘£d(v) of a vertex vâˆˆVğ‘£ğ‘‰v\in V is the size |NGâ€‹(v)|subscriptğ‘ğºğ‘£|N_{G}(v)|. A vertex of degree kğ‘˜k is a kğ‘˜k-vertex. A graph is subcubic if every vertex has degree at mostÂ 333. We let Î”â€‹(G)=maxâ¡{dâ€‹(v):vâˆˆV}Î”ğº:ğ‘‘ğ‘£ğ‘£ğ‘‰\Delta(G)=\max\{d(v):v\in V\}.
For disjoint S,TâŠ†Vğ‘†ğ‘‡ğ‘‰S,T\subseteq V, we say that Sğ‘†S is complete to Tğ‘‡T if every vertex of Sğ‘†S is adjacent to every vertex of Tğ‘‡T. For SâŠ†Vğ‘†ğ‘‰S\subseteq V, Gâ€‹[S]=(S,{uâ€‹v:u,vâˆˆS,uâ€‹vâˆˆE})ğºdelimited-[]ğ‘†ğ‘†conditional-setğ‘¢ğ‘£formulae-sequenceğ‘¢ğ‘£ğ‘†ğ‘¢ğ‘£ğ¸G[S]=(S,\{uv\;:\;u,v\in S,uv\in E\})
is the subgraph of GğºG induced by Sğ‘†S. The disjoint union G+Hğºğ»G+H of graphs GğºG and Hğ»H has vertex set Vâ€‹(G)âˆªVâ€‹(H)ğ‘‰ğºğ‘‰ğ»V(G)\cup V(H) and edge set Eâ€‹(G)âˆªEâ€‹(H)ğ¸ğºğ¸ğ»E(G)\cup E(H). A graph is rğ‘Ÿr-partite, for râ‰¥2ğ‘Ÿ2r\geq 2, if its vertex set admits a partition into rğ‘Ÿr classes such that every edge has its endpoints in different classes. A 222-partite graph is also called bipartite. A graph GğºG is a support for a hypergraph H=(V,ğ’®)ğ»ğ‘‰ğ’®H=(V,\mathcal{S}) if the vertices of GğºG correspond to the vertices of Hğ»H and, for each hyperedge Sâˆˆğ’®ğ‘†ğ’®S\in\mathcal{S}, the subgraph of GğºG induced by Sğ‘†S is connected.
When a bipartite graph G=(A,B,E)ğºğ´ğµğ¸G=(A,B,E) is viewed as a hypergraph H=(A,{Nâ€‹(b):bâˆˆB})ğ»ğ´conditional-setğ‘ğ‘ğ‘ğµH=(A,\{N(b):b\in B\}), then a support Tğ‘‡T for Hğ»H with Tâˆˆâ„‹ğ‘‡â„‹T\in\mathcal{H} is a witness that GğºG is â„‹â„‹\mathcal{H}-convex.
